SEARCH
Module FoundationsF25_2
Package jUnitTesting

Class HarmfulInputTests

java.lang.Object
jUnitTesting.HarmfulInputTests
public class HarmfulInputTests extends Object
Tests showing resilience against SQL injection when using PreparedStatement, and demonstrating the effect of unsafe string concatenation into SQL.

WARNING: Some tests intentionally demonstrate destructive SQL (e.g., DROP TABLE) when executed via unsafe concatenation. Run these tests only in an isolated test database (preferably in-memory H2) and never against a production database or shared file-based DB.

Test lifecycle:

  • setup() — creates a fresh Database instance, connects it, clears any existing data, and creates required thread records.
  • teardown() — attempts to clear database state after each test (best-effort).

Since:
1.0

  • Method Details

    • setup

      @BeforeEach public void setup() throws Exception
      Set up a fresh database state before each test.

      This method:

      1. Creates a new Database helper instance.
      2. Connects to the database.
      3. Clears any existing tables/data to ensure isolation.
      4. Creates default threads used by tests (e.g., "General", "Project").

      Throws:
      Exception - if database connection or setup operations fail

    • teardown

      @AfterEach public void teardown() throws Exception
      Tear down database state after each test.

      This attempts to clear the database so subsequent tests start with a clean state. When a test intentionally drops tables (unsafe demonstration), clearDatabase() may fail; such exceptions are swallowed to allow the test harness to continue.

      Throws:
      Exception - if an unexpected error occurs while attempting teardown

    • testPreparedStatementPreventsDropTable

      @Test @DisplayName("Safe insertion with PreparedStatement resists DROP TABLE injection") public void testPreparedStatementPreventsDropTable() throws Exception
      Verifies that using PreparedStatement prevents SQL injection attempts that include a DROP TABLE payload. The test:
      1. Inserts a safe post via Database.makePost(Post)
      2. Attempts to insert a post whose title contains a DROP TABLE POSTS payload using a PreparedStatement
      3. Asserts that the prepared insert succeeded, the POSTS table still exists, and the malicious-looking string is stored literally.
      Throws:
      Exception - if obtaining the connection or executing SQL fails

    • testUnsafeConcatenationCanDropTable

      @Test @DisplayName("Unsafe concatenation + Statement allows DROP TABLE (demonstration)") public void testUnsafeConcatenationCanDropTable() throws Exception
      Demonstrates the danger of unsafe SQL concatenation by building an SQL string that includes a DROP TABLE payload and executing it with a plain Statement.

      Outcomes depend on H2 configuration:

      • If the engine allows multi-statement execution, the DROP TABLE POSTS may succeed and the test asserts the table is gone.
      • If the engine prevents multi-statement execution, the table will remain and the test asserts it still exists.

      Note: this test intentionally performs an unsafe operation to demonstrate impact; it should be run only in isolated/in-memory test databases.

      Throws:
      Exception - if connection or metadata checks fail

    • testDropAllObjectsInjection

      @Test @DisplayName("Attempt DROP ALL OBJECTS injection and verify database state") public void testDropAllObjectsInjection() throws Exception
      Attempts an unsafe concatenated insertion that includes a DROP ALL OBJECTS payload (H2-specific). Afterwards, verifies the database schema state.

      Behavior:

      • If DROP ALL OBJECTS executed successfully, the database will be wiped and helper methods should indicate missing tables/rows.
      • If execution was prevented by the engine, the table remains and the test asserts that.

      Throws:
      Exception - if obtaining connection or metadata queries fail

    • obtainConnection

      private Connection obtainConnection() throws Exception
      Obtain the underlying JDBC Connection used by the Database helper.

      The helper first attempts to call a getConnection() method reflectively. If that method is not available, it falls back to locating a connection field (possibly private) via reflection and returning its value.

      Returns:
      the active Connection instance used by the Database
      Throws:
      Exception - if a connection cannot be located or retrieved

    • tableExists

      private boolean tableExists(Connection conn, String tableName) throws SQLException
      Check whether the specified table exists in the database connected by conn.

      This uses DatabaseMetaData.getTables(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String[]) and upper-cases tableName for H2 compatibility (H2 stores unquoted identifiers in upper-case).

      Parameters:
      conn - the active JDBC connection
      tableName - the table name to check (case-insensitive)
      Returns:
      true if the table exists, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - if querying metadata fails
